publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in ŠorčuqStadthöhleduring T III Š 72.08

sourceDesc.p: Transcription and translation are based on .

Transcription and references have been transferred from the "Text and Reference Database of the Tocharian A Language" (Gerd Carling Lund University) (funded by the Bank of Sweden Tercentenary Foundation and SCAS).

seg.seg: (just) so it is to the [living] body in turn. Fie, blind passion! 1. But this thing has been shown to me by the master mechanic as a skill in his own
craft. Why should I not let him see my own art as well? Then the painter quickly produced

Darauf zog der Maler sehr schnell [wtl. schnell schnell] Palette(?) [und] Farben hervor und malte noch in derselben Nacht sich selbst als Getöteten an die Wand mit einem Strick (um) den Hals, an einem Haken(?) hängend.

Thereupon the painter quickly, quickly took out [his] palette(?) [and] colours and, in the very same night, onto the wall he painted himself as a killed one with a rope (around) [his] neck, hanging from a hook(?).
a brush(?) and ink(?) and in the same night as one killed, with a rope around his neck,
hanging on a nail, he painted himself opposite(?) the door. But how so? || In the Ṣ.-tune: || The head tilted a little --
the eyes set, with the protruding lips (lit. stretched towards the front) the [last] sighs going out of the throat, hands and feet hanging down,
with the lascivious lower abdomen, a rope around his neck, hanging on a nail (like one) killed, the golden skin of his body having become pale

... einen Strick um den Hals, an einem Haken(?) hängend als Getöteten, ... [so] sich selbst wie leibhaftig gemalt habend/als er sich wie leibhaftig gemalt hatte, nahm er seine Palette(?) [und] ging hinaus(?).
... a rope around [his] neck, hanging from a hook(?) as one killed, ... having painted himself thus as if real, he took his palette(?) and went out(?).
thus he painted himself as if real, took his painting tools and went under cover. 1. When in the morning the mechanic
Als dann morgens der Mechaniker zum Maler kam, sah er das künstliche Mädchen auseinandergefallen und sah [auch] den Maler als [Selbst]-getöteten an einem Haken(?) hängend.
When, in the morning, the mechanic came to the painter, he saw the artificial girl fallen apart and [he also] saw the painter as a killed one, hanging from a hook(?).
came to the painter, he saw the mechanical girl fallen apart and he [also] saw the painter
as a self-killed one. Thereupon he raised his voice as one distraught, being depressed he said: oh what a
pity, what a pity! Thereupon soon the neighbouring people of the land and much folk gathered and
they say: Who was that? Depressed, the mechanic says: behold, you gentlemen, this my misfortune! || In the Ś.-tune: ||

Sehet, [ihr] Herren, dieses mein Unglück! Von den Malermeistern der Malermeister, mein Freund, kam als Gast, mein künstliches Mädchen versah ihm den Dienst. Aus Liebe wohl berührte er das Mädchen, der Mechanismus zerbrach, [und] aus Scham darüber [wtl. aus d[ies]er Scham] tötete sich der Maler selbst, er hängt an einem Haken(?), sehet, [ihr] Guten!

See, lords, this my misfortune! The master painter of master painters, my friend, came as a guest, my artificial girl served him. Out of love, it seems, he touched the girl, the mechanism broke, [and] out of this shame the painter killed himself, he is hanging from a hook(?), see, [you] good ones!
Of the master painters the master of painters, my friend(?), came as a guest, my artificial girl attended to him,

p.note: The translation is largely based on 11-12, and .
The tune has a metre of 20-22-10-15 syllables, the rhythm is 5/5/5/5, 8/7/7, 5/5 and 8/7, respectively.
Restoration yre(ki) according to 342-343 after 22, fn. 5.

div.p: Edition7-8. Siegling's personal copy of p. 7 p. 8.

list.item: a1 ·n·_k\ kapśñaṃ mska_t_ar paṃ hiśtä\ tra_k\ eṅ_k_a_l\ : 1 || _s_as wram nu yaṃtrācāreṃ _k_aṣṣinā ṣñi amokaṃ o – a2 -śśune nṣac la_l_akṣu tā_k\ kyal mā _n_aṣ penu cami ṣñi amo_k\ lkātsi āyi_m\ _t_m_a_ṣ\ pekan_t\ ymā – a3 -_r\ lyu wra_m\ roteyäntu tsko_r_a_ṣ\ tā_m_a-_k\ wṣe poṣṣā ṣñi āñcä_m\ sasrukun_t\ kñu[_k]· (–) a4 -rpyo ṣpinacä\ _l_aṅkmāṃ peka_t _t_am nu _m_an_t\ wäknā || ṣaḍa_p\-devadattenaṃ || ywon_t\ la_p\ tsru y[r]e – a5 – – aśäṃ ton_t\ yoṣmo_ṣ\ ywon_t\ lymenyo ṣuṅ_k_aṣṣ ana_s\ ymāṃ : _l_aṅmāṃ tsa_r_aṃ peyu ārta_k\ – a6 – – kātsyo kñukaṃ spar_p\ ṣpinac _l_aṅmāṃ sasrukun_t\ : wsi yat_s\ kapśiññā _n_askon_t\ – – b1 – – – śy oky āñcä_m\ pāpeku_r_a_ṣ\ kāmat lyu wra_m\ _k_a_l_k\ elā : 1 || _t_m_a_ṣ\ _k_s_ar yaṃtrācār· – – b2 – nacä\ kakmu_r_a_ṣ\ _p_alkāt tā_m\ yan_t_arṣināṃ śomināṃ _p_k_an_t\ _p_k_an_t\ kāklosāṃ _p_alkā_s\ śkaṃ ca (–) b3 -_k_antāṃ sasrukun_t\ ṣpinac _l_aṅmāṃ _t_m_a_ṣ\ wiyo =ki wak cär_k\ klopasu nāṃtsu t_r_aṅ_k_a_ṣ\ hā k(·) b4 -ryapp ā kārya_p\ • _t_m_a_ṣ\ wa_ṣ_k_ar_s\ vārtskāñä\ ypeṣiñi wrasañä\ māk śoṣi kākropu – (–) b5 -ñcä\ kus tā_k\ klopasu nāṃtsu yaṃtrācāre t_r_aṅ_k_a_ṣ\ _p_alkācä\ nācki ñi klo_p\ ca_ṣ\ || śuri (– –) b6 || pe_k_antāśśi _k_aṣṣiśśi _k_aṣṣi pekan_t\ ñi naṣu : loki_t\ yeṣ-ñi yan_t_arṣi śomiṃ cami spa –

The translation is largely based on [[Sieg, Übers. I]]: 11-12, and [[Carling, DThTA]].

a4. The tune has a metre of 20-22-10-15 syllables, the rhythm is 5/5/5/5, 8/7/7, 5/5 and 8/7, respectively.

a4. Restoration yre(ki) according to [[Burlak and Itkin 2010]]: 342-343 after [[Krause and Thomas, TEB II]]: 22, fn. 5.

b5f. The tune has 4x14 syllables, rhythm 7/7.

Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
a2-4 Darauf zog der Maler sehr schnell [wtl. schnell schnell] Palette(?) [und] Farben hervor und malte noch in derselben Nacht sich selbst als Getöteten an die Wand mit einem Strick (um) den Hals, an einem Haken(?) hängend. 314-5
a6-b1 ... einen Strick um den Hals, an einem Haken(?) hängend als Getöteten, ... [so] sich selbst wie leibhaftig gemalt habend/als er sich wie leibhaftig gemalt hatte, nahm er seine Palette(?) [und] ging hinaus(?). 315, fn. 2, 398-90
b1-3 Als dann morgens der Mechaniker zum Maler kam, sah er das künstliche Mädchen auseinandergefallen und sah [auch] den Maler als [Selbst]-getöteten an einem Haken(?) hängend. 188
b5-a1 Sehet, [ihr] Herren, dieses mein Unglück! Von den Malermeistern der Malermeister, mein Freund, kam als Gast, mein künstliches Mädchen versah ihm den Dienst. Aus Liebe wohl berührte er das Mädchen, der Mechanismus zerbrach, [und] aus Scham darüber [wtl. aus d[ies]er Scham] tötete sich der Maler selbst, er hängt an einem Haken(?), sehet, [ihr] Guten! 189-90


  • b3-4, hā k(ā)ryapp ā kāryap: [[Carling, DThTA]] has “pity” (p. 30) and “damage” (p. 148) (TI)
  • a5-a6: [[Sieg, Übers. I]] restore the masculine tärkont, which would fit the meter better than the feminine tärkosāṃ. [[Carling, DThTA]] take kāts to be feminine but none of the attestations seem to involve gender agreement. (BK)
  • a5: [[Pinault 2008]]: 256 corrects atas to a{n}as. (BK)

tämnek|(tä)|(m)n(e)k a1 kapśiññaṃ|kapśñaṃ mäskatär|mskatär paṃ ; hiśt trak eṅkäl_(TA)|eṅkäl : 1 || #1d säs wram nu yaṃtrācāreṃ käṣṣinā ṣñi amokaṃ opäśśune|o(pä)|śśune a2 nṣac laläkṣu tāk kuyal|kyal mā_(TA)|mā näṣ penu cami ṣñi amok_(TA)|amok lkātsi āyim tmäṣ pekant ymā(r ymār|ymā)|r a3 lyu wram roteyäntu tskoräṣ tām|tāmä-k wṣe poṣṣā ṣñi āñcäm sasrukunt kñuk(aṃ sparpyo|spa)|rpyo a4 ṣpinac läṅkmāṃ pekat täm nu mänt wäknā || ṣaḍap-devadattenaṃ || # ywont lap tsru yre(ki) ; a5 – – aśäṃ tont ; yoṣmoṣ ywont lymenyo ; ṣuṅkäṣ|ṣuṅkäṣṣ anas ymāṃ : #1a läṅkmāṃ|läṅmāṃ tsaräṃ , peyu ārtak ; tärkosāṃ|(tä)|(rkosāṃ) a6 kātsyo , kñukaṃ sparp ; ṣpinac läṅkmāṃ|läṅmāṃ , sasrukunt : #1b wsi yats kapśiññā ; näskont – – b1 – – %3 #1c yneśi|(yne)śy oki|oky āñcäm , pāpekuräṣ ; kāmat lyu wram , kälk elā : 1 || #1d tmäṣ ksär yaṃtrācār(e pekäntānac|pekän|tā)nac b2 kakmuräṣ pälkāt tām yantärṣināṃ śomināṃ pkänt pkänt kāklosāṃ pälkā{t} śkaṃ ca(m pekäntāṃ|pe)|käntāṃ b3 sasrukunt ṣpinac läṅkmāṃ|läṅmāṃ tmäṣ wiyo oki|=ki wak cärk klopasu nāṃtsu träṅkäṣ hā kāryap|k(ā)|ryapp b4 ā kāryap • tmäṣ waṣkärs vārtskāñ ypeṣiñi wrasañ māk śoṣi kākropu(ṣ träṅkiñc|träṅki)|ñc b5 kus tāk klopasu nāṃtsu yaṃtrācāre träṅkäṣ pälkāc nācki ñi klop caṣ || śuri(ṣinaṃ) b6 || # pekäntāśśi , käṣṣiśśi ; käṣṣi_(TA)|käṣṣi pekant , ñi naṣu : #1a lokit yeṣ-ñi , yantärṣi ; śomiṃ cami , spa(ktāṃ) #1b

a1 (just) so it is to the [living] body in turn. Fie, blind passion! 1. But this thing has been shown to me by the master mechanic as a skill in his own a2 craft. Why should I not let him see my own art as well? Then the painter quickly produced a3 a brush(?) and ink(?) and in the same night as one killed, with a rope around his neck, a4 hanging on a nail, he painted himself opposite(?) the door. But how so? || In the Ṣ.-tune: || The head tilted a little -- a5 the eyes set, with the protruding lips (lit. stretched towards the front) the [last] sighs going out of the throat, hands and feet hanging down, a6 with the lascivious lower abdomen, a rope around his neck, hanging on a nail (like one) killed, the golden skin of his body having become pale b1 thus he painted himself as if real, took his painting tools and went under cover. 1. When in the morning the mechanic b2 came to the painter, he saw the mechanical girl fallen apart and he [also] saw the painter b3 as a self-killed one. Thereupon he raised his voice as one distraught, being depressed he said: oh what a b4 pity, what a pity! Thereupon soon the neighbouring people of the land and much folk gathered and b5 they say: Who was that? Depressed, the mechanic says: behold, you gentlemen, this my misfortune! || In the Ś.-tune: || b6 Of the master painters the master of painters, my friend(?), came as a guest, my artificial girl attended to him,

div.p: • hā k(ā)ryapp ā kāryap: </bibl> has “pity” (p. 30) and “damage” (p. 148) (TI)</li><li><ref type="ms" target="__a5-a6:"/><bibl><title corresp="ref:sieg1944"/></bibl> restore the masculine <hi>tärkont</hi>, which would fit the meter better than the feminine <hi>tärkosāṃ</hi>. <bibl><title corresp="ref:carlingetal2009"/></bibl> take <hi>kāts</hi> to be feminine but none of the attestations seem to involve gender agreement. (BK)</li><li><ref type="ms" target="__a5:"/><bibl><title corresp="ref:pinault2008"/><citedRange>256</citedRange></bibl> corrects <hi>atas</hi> to <hi>a{n}as</hi>. (BK)</li></ul></p></project_comment>
